page.title: 05SHEEP AT COVENHOPE AYMESTREY
page.content: At present on the farm there are about 30 head of pedigree ewes, these include{British Charollais}sheep and {British Texels. }The sheep are kept mainly to clean up the pastures after the dairy herd. As they are pedigrees the best rams are kept for breeding and the plainer sort are culled early into the Spring lamb market. The ewe lambs are kept to replenish the flock. These are born early January onwards so the ewes have to be housed in mid December and they are fed from here onwards, until they give birth, on hay, wet sugar beet pulp(important to prevent twin-lamb diseases), oats and flake maize. After lambing they are given more concentrates and turned out to grass. All the sheep have to be dipped against sheep scab and maggot fly in July and October and are also treated for worms, fluke and footrot.
